componenttextpreview: Oh, I apologize. Can you provide an outlook for the 2015 state excise tax environment?
componenttext: Oh, I apologize. Can you provide an outlook for the 2015 state excise tax environment?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, we're always cautious at the beginning of the year, aren't we? And we've all seen that the state excise tax environment has been more moderate in the last several years than it has been previous. But we go into each year prepared to answer the
componenttext: Yes. Well, we're always cautious at the beginning of the year, aren't we? And we've all seen that the state excise tax environment has been more moderate in the last several years than it has been previous. But we go into each year prepared to answer the call because, as you've observed and others have observed, as soon as the legislatures come back in January, we see the proposals start to roll in, and there are number of them that are out there. We have very good government affairs people that point out that this is unfair to tobacco consumers, and these products are already highly taxed, but we'll have to see how the year plays out. It's been a fairly moderate environment over the last several years, and we hope that plays out in '15.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bonnie Herzog of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bonnie Herzog of Wells Fargo.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So in terms of your EPS growth guidance of 7% to 9% for this year, it is in line with your historical trends and seems very conservative, given the strong pricing and tremendous cost savings you have this year. So I assume you'll be fully reinvesting thes
componenttext: So in terms of your EPS growth guidance of 7% to 9% for this year, it is in line with your historical trends and seems very conservative, given the strong pricing and tremendous cost savings you have this year. So I assume you'll be fully reinvesting these savings into your different businesses. So my first question is why not let some of the strength flow to the bottom line? And then second, could you give us a sense of what the different investment buckets are, for instance, 70% of the savings will be invested in e-cigs vapor, 30% in combustible? Just again trying to get a sense of your priorities.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me offer you a slightly different perspective. In previous years, we've come out, I think, for the last several years at 6% to 9%, not at 7% to 9%, and the factors that went into our judgment this year about how to guide include some of the thin
componenttext: Sure. Let me offer you a slightly different perspective. In previous years, we've come out, I think, for the last several years at 6% to 9%, not at 7% to 9%, and the factors that went into our judgment this year about how to guide include some of the things we've already spoken about on the call, which is a modestly improving situation for our adult tobacco consumer. Obviously, we have the benefit of some FETRA payments. But we, I think, pointed out in our release, we have some pension and health care cost changes due to long-term assumptions. And so every year, you put your guidance together, and you have puts and takes about what you're going to do. Some years, we invest. Some years, we have factors, which are flowing in the other direction. I think 7% to 9% in the current environment is a strong signal about the confidence we have in our business and our operating company plans. And Howard, you may want to supplement that answer.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I think you covered it, Marty. The only other thing I would point out, and this has been with us for some time, and I think has been quite orderly, but we're continuing to unwind the PMCC business, and as that progresses, there are fewer and fewe
componenttext: Yes. No, I think you covered it, Marty. The only other thing I would point out, and this has been with us for some time, and I think has been quite orderly, but we're continuing to unwind the PMCC business, and as that progresses, there are fewer and fewer asset sales that are available. So that's another element that plays into the overall company performance.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's really helpful, guys, and I think it also highlights the consistency of your business as well with all the different puts and takes that you mentioned. And then I do have a broad question on the consumer and up trading. So I'm certainly heari
componenttext: Okay. That's really helpful, guys, and I think it also highlights the consistency of your business as well with all the different puts and takes that you mentioned. And then I do have a broad question on the consumer and up trading. So I'm certainly hearing from a lot of the retailers that consumers' greater disposable income is leading to up trading. So is this too what you've seen in your Marlboro franchise? And has there been mix shift to premium Marlboro, if I could call it that? And also, you generated the strong net price realization in cigs, but I'd be curious to hear from you what happens when gas prices go back up? In other words, how sustainable do you think the strong pricing in cigs will be, especially if and when gas prices rise?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me try to comment on a couple of those to try to help you. I think gas prices for us, historically, we have not called out gas prices as one of the principal drivers of consumer behavior, although we acknowledge that it had some effect. To us, i
componenttext: Okay. Let me try to comment on a couple of those to try to help you. I think gas prices for us, historically, we have not called out gas prices as one of the principal drivers of consumer behavior, although we acknowledge that it had some effect. To us, it was really more about the unemployment rate, consumer confidence and housing starts. Now the way that gasoline prices have gone down so precipitously has obviously had a bigger effect on the consumer, right? The C stores, as you and others have pointed out, are seeing better traffic, and I don't think there's any question that it's contributing to consumers feeling better about their economy situation. But historically, Bonnie, we have not called that out as one of the big 3 drivers. So I don't know what people are expecting for gasoline prices, but it probably will not have that much more of an effect. We did have very good pricing, and the way that we achieved pricing, as you know, is we took list pricing in 2014, combined $0.13 a pack, and then, as always, we can moderate our promotional allowances, and we did so last year. We moderated our allowances on special blend, Marlboro Special Blend and on Black. And as you know, we're able to do that quite tactically by state by using our SPP [ph] tools. So we did see a year in which we think we could take some pricing, and I think you can see that in the numbers for 2014.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: So 1 follow-up and another question. So on a follow-up perspective. So Howard, you've talked about the fourth quarter being impacted by some timing of expense items. Just on a full year basis, though, your marketing and R&D expenses were up over $200 mill
componenttext: So 1 follow-up and another question. So on a follow-up perspective. So Howard, you've talked about the fourth quarter being impacted by some timing of expense items. Just on a full year basis, though, your marketing and R&D expenses were up over $200 million. So I just want us to get a bit better sense of where that spending was allocated in 2014, how much is that sort of sustainable into 2015 and thinking about the guidance for 2015.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think with regard to marketing and R&D, I really don't feel that there's been any dramatic departure this year versus prior years that I would call out, with probably the one exception being that this was the year that we made some significant inve
componenttext: Yes, I think with regard to marketing and R&D, I really don't feel that there's been any dramatic departure this year versus prior years that I would call out, with probably the one exception being that this was the year that we made some significant investments through new market in the e-vapor category. And obviously, that's had an impact on our R&D investments as we build that product pipeline, and certainly, there's a marketing that supports that as well, but that's really the primary impact there.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe on the e-vapor category itself. If you look at some of the measure channel data, the category has slowed. You've obviously expanded the MarkTen distribution. I'm just wondering if you can talk about your assessment about the category
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe on the e-vapor category itself. If you look at some of the measure channel data, the category has slowed. You've obviously expanded the MarkTen distribution. I'm just wondering if you can talk about your assessment about the category generally at this point. And then you also talked about more of a disciplined approach to building MarkTen. So can you just elaborate on that? And in light of the dynamics, how you're thinking about the performance that you're seeing from MarkTen?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, let's start with the category. Our estimate is that the consumer spending in 2014 increased by about 50% to about $2 billion, and that's compared to a year before, which I think you've seen the numbers, of roughly a 160% increase. So you can s
componenttext: Sure. Well, let's start with the category. Our estimate is that the consumer spending in 2014 increased by about 50% to about $2 billion, and that's compared to a year before, which I think you've seen the numbers, of roughly a 160% increase. So you can see that it has slowed, although its 50% increase is still fairly large. It's growing about traditional trade channels, and it's also growing in vape shops, which are harder to get a line of sight into. To dimensional that spent, though, $80 billion is spent on conventional tobacco products versus the 2 that we estimate. So just to put it in its proper context. With respect to Nu Mark, our belief is, is that, that is an interesting enough category for us to participate in and to aspire to have leadership in. That is leadership that will be achieved over the long term and for the long term, which is why we use these words about financially disciplined and over time. We want to participate there. We believe Nu Mark had a very good year. Gosh, we got the MarkTen product in 130,000 retail stores, and I mean, that's easy to stay and that's hard to do, and so our sales force at Nu Mark did a great job there. They rolled out, as we mentioned in our remarks, the 2.5 product. Consumers continue to look for their product. And so I think a lot of what's going to happen with vapor is about manufacturers trying to bring out products that better satisfy their consumers, and that's what Nu Mark is doing. It's for the long term. It will be for the long term, and we are learning our way in with our consumer and using a disciplined approach. But with the acquisition of Green Smoke and their people and their technology in addition to Nu Mark, I am very encouraged about what we have in the pipeline for MarkTen.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then, lastly, Howard, just in terms of 2015 guidance, can you tell us how much your buyback is incorporated?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then, lastly, Howard, just in terms of 2015 guidance, can you tell us how much your buyback is incorporated?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm not going to guide at that level. I think we've previously talked about the fact that we have an existing share repurchase program in place. It's got a little over $500 million left, and we had communicated we expected to finish that by the end o
componenttext: Yes, I'm not going to guide at that level. I think we've previously talked about the fact that we have an existing share repurchase program in place. It's got a little over $500 million left, and we had communicated we expected to finish that by the end of the year. So that hasn't changed, and certainly, any share repurchase plans we have are incorporated into the 7% to 9% guidance.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Owen Bennett of Nomura.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Owen Bennett of Nomura.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just following on the vapor question then, I guess, have you got any updates on potential timescale and for commercialization of PMI's heat-not-burn?
componenttext: Just following on the vapor question then, I guess, have you got any updates on potential timescale and for commercialization of PMI's heat-not-burn?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, we're working on it. That has to go through the FDA process, as you know, and we're working closely with them on it, and I think we feel like we're making good progress, and I think PMI would tell you the same thing but I can't give you a date because
componenttext: No, we're working on it. That has to go through the FDA process, as you know, and we're working closely with them on it, and I think we feel like we're making good progress, and I think PMI would tell you the same thing but I can't give you a date because it's subject to the FDA's processes.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Growe of Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Growe of Stifel.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just I have 2 questions. I think a bit of a follow-up from earlier questions. The first one would be, Marty, in relation to Marlboro and the discount products on the market today, that price gap is quite narrow at 32%. It's been there for several years. Y
componenttext: Just I have 2 questions. I think a bit of a follow-up from earlier questions. The first one would be, Marty, in relation to Marlboro and the discount products on the market today, that price gap is quite narrow at 32%. It's been there for several years. You talked about, I think, to an earlier question like the improving consumer environment. Can we see that price gap expand? So therefore, are economic conditions in such a place that it will allow for premium products to take a little bit more pricing than discount products?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: That would be our hope, of course, as we try to maximize income in the Smokable segment, which is the price gaps have been higher at times in its history, and -- but you have to be thoughtful about you do that and when, but certainly, that would be in our
componenttext: That would be our hope, of course, as we try to maximize income in the Smokable segment, which is the price gaps have been higher at times in its history, and -- but you have to be thoughtful about you do that and when, but certainly, that would be in our interest of maximizing income.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then another question on the -- call it the other division, where you have PMCC and Nu Mark, and I know it's hard -- you can characterize each of those businesses and how they perform. But you had a large investment and a huge national launch in
componenttext: Okay. And then another question on the -- call it the other division, where you have PMCC and Nu Mark, and I know it's hard -- you can characterize each of those businesses and how they perform. But you had a large investment and a huge national launch in MarkTen in 2014, and the investments of that operating loss in that division obviously expanded. I'm just curious, is it such that you got a full pipeline that, that operating loss couldn't come down? Or has the Nu Mark business, which is obviously generating some decent sales now, gotten to a point to where we should see less operating loss in the coming year?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I know that everybody is trying to get under the All Other, but we've really got 2 things operating there. We're investing in Nu Mark, which make sense for the long term. And Howard has pointed out that as we wind down PMCC, we have fewer asset sales
componenttext: Yes, I know that everybody is trying to get under the All Other, but we've really got 2 things operating there. We're investing in Nu Mark, which make sense for the long term. And Howard has pointed out that as we wind down PMCC, we have fewer asset sales, and they tend to be lumpy from time to time. So that's what's going on over there, and we're just not going to guide down too much deeper than that, Chris, if you'll allow me.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I understand. Maybe, I think you may have mentioned earlier, just to follow on about a strong pipeline of products at Nu Mark. Should we expect some more activity behind product launches this year in '15? Is that a fair question?
componenttext: I understand. Maybe, I think you may have mentioned earlier, just to follow on about a strong pipeline of products at Nu Mark. Should we expect some more activity behind product launches this year in '15? Is that a fair question?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's fair question, and I'm going to reserve my answer so that I don't hand out my competitive plans on the phone. But yes, you should be thinking about this, I think, in terms of the category. We expect to have products that will be launched, that
componenttext: Well, it's fair question, and I'm going to reserve my answer so that I don't hand out my competitive plans on the phone. But yes, you should be thinking about this, I think, in terms of the category. We expect to have products that will be launched, that will be better and better, as I expect that other people are planning similarly. I think that's exactly the nature of the category right now. We've got good plans for that.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Lavery of CLSA.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Lavery of CLSA.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you just give a sense of what some of the investments -- what type of investments would be ideal for the savings that you've got coming from the buyout? And just in terms of equity building, obviously, you have some relatively limited options in some
componenttext: Can you just give a sense of what some of the investments -- what type of investments would be ideal for the savings that you've got coming from the buyout? And just in terms of equity building, obviously, you have some relatively limited options in some of your marketing capabilities. But can you just give a sense of what the tools are that would be highest priority for how you would think about applying some of those extra funds?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, again, I'm not going to lay that out to tell everybody exactly how we're going to spend our assets to improve our business. But you've seen us over time do such things as develop the Marlboro architecture, to improve our Marlboro digital site, to ro
componenttext: Well, again, I'm not going to lay that out to tell everybody exactly how we're going to spend our assets to improve our business. But you've seen us over time do such things as develop the Marlboro architecture, to improve our Marlboro digital site, to roll out new products, like Rich Blue and Black and so forth. There's lots of places for us to invest in our businesses. Our goal is to keep our brand franchises strong and relevant, and there's lots of tools to do that even, as you point out, in a category which has higher regulation. And then we have, obviously, as has previously been described, some investments to make in our innovative products. So that's how I think about it, Michael, at a high level. I'm just not going to lay it out in detail, as I'm sure you can understand.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, that's fair enough. And just looking at the 4Q market share numbers even with the improving consumer health you had, the discount segment really driving the share gains with Marlboro flat, is that a focus for 2015 to try to -- obviously, I'm sure yo
componenttext: Sure, that's fair enough. And just looking at the 4Q market share numbers even with the improving consumer health you had, the discount segment really driving the share gains with Marlboro flat, is that a focus for 2015 to try to -- obviously, I'm sure you enjoy getting the lift in discount share. But is there a way you want to try to manage that to bring Marlboro further ahead or is the sort of steady-state also -- how do you think about Marlboro versus the total portfolio and what the priorities are in terms of just how you approach that?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a good question. Well, our aim is modest share momentum on Marlboro. And we previously characterized, I think, that as -- if we get a 1/10 or 2/10 a year, that's great for Marlboro. Listen, our focus is on premium. Over 90% of our shipments are
componenttext: Yes, it's a good question. Well, our aim is modest share momentum on Marlboro. And we previously characterized, I think, that as -- if we get a 1/10 or 2/10 a year, that's great for Marlboro. Listen, our focus is on premium. Over 90% of our shipments are premium, but there is a discount segment, and so we try to participate there, and L&M is a great offering at that price point.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then, lastly, on Green Smoke, it's been the MarkTen rollout you've taken nationally. What's the next step for Green Smoke? Would that follow it?
componenttext: Okay, great. And then, lastly, on Green Smoke, it's been the MarkTen rollout you've taken nationally. What's the next step for Green Smoke? Would that follow it?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we're working on that. I mentioned, I think, to someone else that we've been integrating Green Smoke. They've really helped us quite a lot on the front end with supply chain. They had a well-established supply chain, and we've been relying on them q
componenttext: Well, we're working on that. I mentioned, I think, to someone else that we've been integrating Green Smoke. They've really helped us quite a lot on the front end with supply chain. They had a well-established supply chain, and we've been relying on them quite heavily to help us in that regard. They have very good people, and they do have a good technology pipeline. We've been integrating all that in 2014. Remember, we closed in this, I think, in April, if memory serves. And so we've now been integrating that, and we have an integrated pipeline of products, as well as we become more efficient with those 2 organizations. So yes, I would expect to see more from the combined Nu Mark Green Smoke assets.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Nik Modi of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Nik Modi of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: First, I want to just say congrats to Howard, Dave and Billy on the all-new roles. So congrats to you guys. Two questions from my end. The first one is on the Marlboro architecture. I mean, it's been a couple of years now since it's been implemented. And
componenttext: First, I want to just say congrats to Howard, Dave and Billy on the all-new roles. So congrats to you guys. Two questions from my end. The first one is on the Marlboro architecture. I mean, it's been a couple of years now since it's been implemented. And I was wondering if maybe you had some context perspective you can share in terms of brand equity scores or any kind of indicator, quantitative indicator on kind of what the effect has been. I mean, clearly, we've seen the Marlboro franchise do well over this timeframe. So I just wondered if you have some more granularity on some of the quantification behind Marlboro? And the second question is, and this is, I guess, more strategic. It seems like the Super Premium Cigarettes segment is doing fairly well and has been doing fairly well, and there's really not that many players in that market. I just wondered from a strategic standpoint how PM USA really thinks about that?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me tackle those in turn. Good questions both. You're right, Marlboro architecture has been a terrific boost for our business. We talked previously about having the flavor families and allowing different marketing approaches in the families and wh
componenttext: Yes, let me tackle those in turn. Good questions both. You're right, Marlboro architecture has been a terrific boost for our business. We talked previously about having the flavor families and allowing different marketing approaches in the families and what it's done for Marlboro.com has been great. I think that's shown up in the performance of Marlboro. With respect to any quantitative brand equity data, we may talk about that some at CAGNY. So if I can just ask you to hold tight on that, I think we'll have some further information for you in that regard. With respect to super premium, the way -- let me just mention the strategic approach to this, which is we're always looking for places in the market where there is business, where we either are under indexed or we don't have an offering, and so we look at things all the time. And while I don't have anything to announce about that, I can assure you, we look at places to build our business both there and elsewhere.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Media representatives are now invited to ask questions. [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Michael Felberbaum of the Associated Press.
componenttext: Media representatives are now invited to ask questions. [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Michael Felberbaum of the Associated Press.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could give a little bit more color more broadly on the strength of the Marlboro brand and how it's been able to sort of stave off some increased competition, as well as whether the economic -- recovering economic situation.
componenttext: I was wondering if you could give a little bit more color more broadly on the strength of the Marlboro brand and how it's been able to sort of stave off some increased competition, as well as whether the economic -- recovering economic situation.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Marlboro is a fantastic product for adult smokers that comes with decades of leadership, with lots of innovation and with lots of offerings for people who are in the category, and it has consistently grown its share over decades. We are the stewards
componenttext: Well, Marlboro is a fantastic product for adult smokers that comes with decades of leadership, with lots of innovation and with lots of offerings for people who are in the category, and it has consistently grown its share over decades. We are the stewards of this brand, and we pay a good deal of attention to Marlboro. That speaks both to the product's function and to its equity, and that's been Marlboro's story. I commented earlier on the call about we see that the economy is strengthening a bit, hopefully, for our adult tobacco consumers. We certainly hope that's going to be the case in 2015.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 30, 2015

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Altria Group 2015 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is scheduled to last about 1 hour, including remarks by Altria's management and a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Altria Group 2015 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is scheduled to last about 1 hour, including remarks by Altria's management and a question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Ms.  Knakmuhs, Vice President, Investor Relations for Altria Client Services. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us. We're here this morning with Marty Barrington, Altria's CEO; and Bill Gifford, Altria's CFO to discuss Altria's 2015 first quarter business results. During our call today, unless otherwise stated, we are compari
componenttext: Good morning, and thank you for joining us. We're here this morning with Marty Barrington, Altria's CEO; and Bill Gifford, Altria's CFO to discuss Altria's 2015 first quarter business results. During our call today, unless otherwise stated, we are comparing results to the same period in 2014. Earlier today, we issued a press release regarding our first quarter results. For a detailed review about them, please review the earnings release on our website at altria.com or via the Altria investor app. Our remarks contain forward-looking and cautionary statements and projections of future results. Please review the forward-looking and cautionary statement section at the end of today's earnings release for various factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from projections. Future dividend payments and share repurchases remains subject to the discretion of Altria's board. And the timing of share repurchases depends on marketplace conditions and other factors. Altria reports its financial result in accordance with U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles. Today's call will contain various operating results on both a reported an adjusted basis, which excludes items that affect the comparability of reported results. Descriptions of these non-GAAP financial measures and reconciliations are included in today's earnings release, which is available on our website, and via the Altria investor app. Now I'll turn the call over to Marty.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sarah. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining our call. Altria had strong start in 2015. Our core tobacco businesses continue to deliver on their strategies back by the strength of the leading premium brands. Each of our reportable segment
componenttext:
Thanks, Sarah. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining our call. Altria had strong start in 2015. Our core tobacco businesses continue to deliver on their strategies back by the strength of the leading premium brands. Each of our reportable segments grew operating company's income and expanded their margins. Altria grew it's adjusted diluted EPS by 10.5%, paid approximately $1 billion in dividends and repurchased 3.6 million shares in the first quarter, and earlier this morning we reaffirmed our guidance for 2015 full year adjusted diluted EPS growth of 7% to 9%. 
Here are some important highlights from the quarter. PM USA delivered on its multiple segment strategy of maximizing income while maintaining modest share momentum on Marlboro over time. The segment produced outstanding results in the first quarter driven by higher pricing, higher volume and Marlboro retail share growth. PM USA has invested steadily today's press in Marlboro and those investment continue to pay off. As a result, the smokable segment grew adjusted operating company's income by over 12% in the quarter. PM USA's reported cigarettes shipment once grew 1.6% in the quarter, benefited from a moderation in the industry decline rate, trade inventory movements and retail share gains. In the machine-made large cigar categories, John Middleton continued to strengthen its leadership position in the profitable tipped cigar segment. The company posted strong double-digit volume growth in the quarter, driven primarily by Black & Mild. 
In the smokeless products segment, USSTC grew first quarter operating company's income by 5% and expanded its operating company's income margin by 1 percentage points to over 63%. USSTC estimates that it's adjusted smokeless segment volumes grew approximately 4% in the quarter or smokeless industry volumes grew 2% over the past 12 months. Copenhagen and Skoal grew their combined retail share by 0.5 percentage points in the quarter. 
Turning to innovative tobacco products. Nu Mark remains focus on building a robust portfolio of innovative tobacco products for adult smokers and vapors. Nu Mark began shipping its next-generation e-vapor product, MarkTen XL into lead markets this month. 
In the line segment, segment posted a quarter of nearly 23% operating company's income growth, primarily through improved premium mix. In the first quarter, equity earnings from our SABMiller investment for negatively affected by SABMiller special items and unfavorable currency impacts from a stronger dollar. The investment continues to support our strong balance sheet and provides cash through its dividend. 
So we came into 2015 with momentum in our first quarter results reflect another quarter of strong execution against our well-defined strategies. We believe our businesses are positioned to help us deliver against our full year guidance.
Billy will now discuss our business returns in more detail.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Marty. Our smokeable products segment helped drive adjustment diluted EPS growth of 10.5% in the first quarter. The smokeless product segment and fewer shares also contributed to that growth. The smokeable products segment delivered strong adju
componenttext:
Thank you, Marty. Our smokeable products segment helped drive adjustment diluted EPS growth of 10.5% in the first quarter. The smokeless product segment and fewer shares also contributed to that growth. The smokeable products segment delivered strong adjusted operating company's income growth of 12.6%, primarily driven by higher pricing, higher shipment volume and lower resolution expenses, due primarily to the dthat end of the federal tobacco quarter buyout payments. Despite cost being higher in the quarter, due primarily to higher pension and benefit cost and the time of SG&A spending, the smokable segment expanded it's adjusted OCA margins by 2.3 percentage points. Volume was also strong, after adjusting trade inventory changes and other factors, PM USA estimates and that its first quarter shipment volume was essentially unchanged, and the total industry volumes declined approximately 0.5%. For the quarter, PM USA grew Marlboro retail share by 3/10 of the share to 44% and grew its total cigarettes categories retail by 0.4 of the share point. share gains also contributed to PM USA's first quarter performance as the brand continue to grow its share while the overall industry discount categories decline in the quarter. In the total machine large cigar categories, Black & Mild retail sales declined 6/10 of a share point in the first quarter. As Marty mentioned, Middleton continue to concentrate on the more profitable tipped cigar segment where Black & Mild gain share. In the smokeless products segment, operating company's income increased 5% in the first quarter as higher pricing was partially offset by higher promotional investments. After adjusting for trade inventory changes and other factors, USSTC estimates that it's domestic smokeless product shipment product grew approximately 4% in the quarter, while the industry grew approximately 2% over the past 12 months. Copenhagen and Skoal's combined retail share grew 5/10 of a share point in the quarter to 51.2%. Copenhagen's retail share 1 share point, while Skoal declined 5/10 a share point. 
The line segment delivered very strong results in the first quarter. Shipment grew operating company's by 22.7% in the first quarter, primarily driven by improved premium mix. Shipments increased by 0.5% in the quarter. That wraps up our operating results. Marty and now we'll take your questions. While the call is being compiled, lets cover a few items. As a reminder, comparisons were made against the first quarter of 2014, unless we note otherwise. Marlboro's price gap versus the lowest effective price cigarettes was 31% in the first quarter, down 2 percentage points. For the first quarter, Marlboro net pack price was $6.06, up $0.15, and the lowest effective price cigarette was $4.62, up $0.17. The estimated weighted average cigarettes excise tax was $1.49 per pack for the first quarter, up $0.01. 
Wholesale inventory changes were one factor PM USA U.S. as adjusted PM USA and industry volumes. PM USA estimates that its wholesale inventories were approximately 2.6 billion units at the end of the first quarter 2015 and 2.4 billion units at the end of the fourth quarter of 2014. At the end of the first quarter of 2014, PM USA's wholesale inventories were estimated to be approximately 2.5 billion units. PM USA estimates that cigarette industry wholesale inventory levels were 5.5 billion units at the end of the first quarter of 2015 and 5.4 billion units at the end of the fourth quarter of 2014. PM USA estimates that first quarter of 2014 wholesale inventory levels were 5.5 billion units. Copenhagen's price gap worse as the leading discount brand was 29% in the first quarter, down 3 percentage points. Copenhagen's retail price was $4.22 from the first quarter, up $0.13. The price of the leading discount brand was $3.26 in the first quarter, up $0.17. CapEx was $48 million for the first quarter, depreciation and amortization was $49 million for the quarter. Operator, do we have any questions?

componenttext: Sure. Let's start with Marlboro Black. It continues to do a terrific job. In fact, it's grown for 17 consecutive quarters. We don't buy the shares out by SKUs as you know, Owen, but Marlboro Black is doing a job, particularly in the important segment of adult smokers 21 to 29. I hope you had a chance to see our remarks at of our vapor business. Our aspiration there is to succeed in the long-term. What that means is your morning with appropriate dispatch, but with financial discipline, always learning from the consumer and what we're working on right now in additional to our distribution and brand building is product development. Consumers are telling eBay per manufacturers that the products are not yet there. That's why you see us improving our product development pipeline. And to be sure, shares is important, but it will be important as soon as the products are established with consumers. So we are not unduly focused on share, we're focused on getting the right products in the consumer's hands.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: My first question is on consumption. Given the strong industry cigarette volume and the decelerating smokeless industry volume, do you have a sense of underlying total tobacco consumption when considering both of these categories? And then you believe it's rising and it's why? And then, maybe touch on your outlook for the cigarette decline rates. Is it 3% to 4% decline rate realistic going forward?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great, thanks for those questions. Let me start with cigarette volume. We don't forecast volume as you know. It's been 3% to 4% over the last several years, and we think that you have to look at that over time. To be sure this quarter, it is a break
componenttext: Okay, great, thanks for those questions. Let me start with cigarette volume. We don't forecast volume as you know. It's been 3% to 4% over the last several years, and we think that you have to look at that over time. To be sure this quarter, it is a break, but it's only a quarter, so we'll have to see. Probably the best answer to your question about consumption is, is the total consumption rate over the last several years as measured by government sources, which has been declining at about call it 1% to 1.5% total pounds. So that takes into account Bonnie all of the products that tobacco consumers are trying. And of course, it's a dynamic time. We have seen more moment among the categories. That's probably the best marker.

componenttext: I will try to give a little help. Its in the all other category. So we don't going to break that out in too much into that. But we're in an investment mode. And that's the best way to understand it. And in response to Owen's question, I pointed out that we have a lot of work underway to make sure we have a robust portfolio of products, because that's what the consumer saying to everyone, which is "I'm willing to try this products, but they're not quite there." So we are continually working to improve our that's why we've come out with MarkTen XL, twice the battery size and so forth. And so I think that's a way to understand it, and we're going to be an investment board, but we do it in a financially way always cognizant of our long-term financial goal of 7% to 9% growth in our EPS, and we've been able to pull that off and I'm confident that we will over time.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Okay, thank you. And then speaking of MarkTen XL, when do expect that to be a nationwide expansion. I think you mentioned you're out into lead markets? And then how incremental do you this is going to be, and then how concerned are you with cannibalization for that extension?

componenttext: Well, we'll talk about national once we get in lead markets and we see how it does. That's out innovation system, which is to put products in consumer's hands, conducting experiments about the offering is interesting to them, find out how we can improve it and then we will go forward. And you saw how we did that in MarkTen, and that's what you should expect with MarkTen XL.

componenttext: Yes, and good questions both. Look our focus is on the premium end of the business, more than 90% of PM USA cigarettes shipments are premium, and that's where the action is for us. But of course, there is the discount segment out there. Its declining over time. The real reason that we're growing our discount business there is because of L&M. It's a product that's price competitively in the marketplace and its doing great. So it's not our principal focus, but it does help the business, albeit small.

componenttext: Thanks for questions. Let me go out at this way. We had net pricing realization in the cigarette in the smokable segment more than 5%, so we can say that despite the fact that the price gap has narrowed, where as you pointed out taking strong pricing, which is great. The reason the price gap has narrowed in the quarter is because some discount brands increased their pricing faster than the premium brands did, and that's what accounts for the math including some frankly when you do the math and the price caps. So price gaps are important metric as we've spoken about, and we keep an eye on them, but boy, to have a quarter where we can grow our volume, grow our margin, great strong pricing realization, you can see the result of that Chris with nearly 13% operating company income growth, that's pretty good for us price gap narrowing or not. Billy you want a word about promotional spend?

componenttext: So I guess, I guess I wanted to just go back to the cigarette consumption question, and I hear you, this is 1 quarter we really have to look at in a longer-term basis, but I don't recall a quarter where you had this kind of volume performance with the price growth that you're seeing across all the players. So I'm just wondering if you could give us a little bit more color, just in terms of the sustainability of this kind of performance within the current macro and competitive backdrops. If there is anything in terms of the investments that a lot of the players have made and perhaps equity building initiatives that kind of driving some of that as well, because it seems to kind of imply that historically when you saw the volume performance really come to typically it was associated with lower pricing, and certainly that's not we're seeing today?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I should give you a bit more color trying to help you with it. You are right. It has been some time since we've seen numbers like this, part of it is the comp versus a year ago. I mean the volume was down pretty significant in the first quarter of '1
componenttext: Yes. I should give you a bit more color trying to help you with it. You are right. It has been some time since we've seen numbers like this, part of it is the comp versus a year ago. I mean the volume was down pretty significant in the first quarter of '14 as you remember. But there is no denying that several factors at play here. The economy is improving, it is improving for our consumers finally, happily after this very difficult time during the recession. We have the phenomenon of dropping gas prices, and it occurs for us at a time after we've made a very significant investments in Marlboro, we the Marlboro We launch Marlboro Black. I would say all of those factors came together to contribute what's a very strong quarter for PM USA. That's our analysis for our business at least.

componenttext: Okay. And then Billy, just thinking about the SABMiller contribution. Clearly, the affect and some of the headwinds from the macro perspective is depressing SABMiller contribution right now. It's a business that obviously you don't necessarily have a control were in terms of the operating performance. How do you sort of think about your 7% to 9% earnings growth to the extent that if SABMiller currency continues to weaken, do you have levers either buyback at the operating line that you can offset the weakness or because it's sort of outside of your control, do kind of look at that as more of a transient factor?

componenttext: Yes, Judy, I think when you think about SABMiller asset. It's been a great asset for us. It's performed very well. We are talking about 1 quarter, and you mentioned the negative drivers on that equity income year-over-year, one special items, which were primarily related to asset impairment and then the negative currency drag. We don't provide that down to that level for the total year. But now at the beginning of the year when we provided guidance, we incorporate a number of factors and SAB was incorporated in that.

componenttext: Okay. So basically you have a view of how SABMiller would performed throughout the year, and that's just baked in to your guidance. But to the extent that SABMiller piece gets worse than your anticipation, I guess the question is really do you have other levers to kind of drive the offset?

componenttext: Yes, I think Judy, overall you heard us guidance today. We feel good about that and we feel good about where the business is.

componenttext: I do think Judy, its Marti, your reference to levers is exactly correct as we different the Altria offering. We have numerous levers that we can use to try to meet our long-term goal of 7% to 9%, and if you look over the last several years, we've been able to do that, as various businesses have been up or down.

componenttext: Two questions,  first I want to ask about the performance in the smokeless products segment. And the specifically the acceleration in consumption for your products during the quarter, the improvement to 4%. Marty I just wanted your assessment of what actions you've taken or what factors during the quarter would have driven that acceleration. Is that a portion of perhaps addressing the value proposition around some of the brands and the degree of pricing that you've taken or would you attribute some of that to tactical efforts that you made on Skoal or whether you're seeing any impact there?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think you've identified the 2 drivers. One is Copenhagen continues to grow strongly. You see it grew a share point in the quarter, and I do think actions you're taking on Skoal are improving. In fact, if you look at the quarterly results for Skoal
componenttext: Sure. I think you've identified the 2 drivers. One is Copenhagen continues to grow strongly. You see it grew a share point in the quarter, and I do think actions you're taking on Skoal are improving. In fact, if you look at the quarterly results for Skoal, it's down a 0.5 a share point but it's the fourth consecutive quarter where it's narrowed those share losses year-over-year. We gave it a new equity campaign. We have terrific equity-based promotions, I think that are improving its relationship with its consumer side. And then as you know, we're been working on the price gaps on Skoal I think all of that is helping to steady up Skoal, and that's spot on strategies. I think it's the combination of Copenhagen's continued growth and our would work on the value equation on Skoal.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I think we saw more improvement in USD volumes than we did for the category overall. But would you say there is any change in the level of interaction between smokeless and other alternatives -- others smokable alternatives?

componenttext: Yes, I know it's just hard to tease that out right now. It's been a couple of quarters. We do know that some of the group previously in smokeless was due to cigarette smokers coming into the category. We now know that there are vapor alternatives. We now have a recovering economies, just really hard to tease out that what exactly those factors are. But we will be able to do that over time, I would expect.

componenttext: Probably short-term noise, although untipped does continue to grow. We're trying to do as you know, is the balance the share question with profitability, and in this segment we always tried to maximize income first. So Black & Mild have a very strong position in the segment that is providing, frankly most of the profitability, we think that's the course at this time.

componenttext: So not to believe the point, but I do also have a question on smokeless tobacco. Marty, we talked a lot about price in the cigarette. And then clearly, they are holding up quite well. Can you just remind us how you guys think about price elasticity in the smokeless segment?

componenttext: Yes, we have some proprietary models for that that allow us to try to get some sense, but not as highly developed as you might expect in the category that's been around as long as cigarettes, but that's really proprietary view of it, which I'm not prepared to talk about on the phone candidly.

componenttext: Okay, fair enough. As we look ahead to the mix shift that's ongoing in the cigarette segments, to say as the consumer continues to hold up, can you point back to another time where we've seen this much kind of trade up or in trade up and how we should think about that trajectory continuing all of the from a macro perspective?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we do know that when adult tobacco consumers are feeling better about their economic situation, they want to be in premium brands. And in this category, the premium brand they want to be in his Marlboro. We've see that several times. If you back go
componenttext: Well, we do know that when adult tobacco consumers are feeling better about their economic situation, they want to be in premium brands. And in this category, the premium brand they want to be in his Marlboro. We've see that several times. If you back go back in history, for example, when you look at Marlboro Friday price gaps get out of line the consumer was not feeling good about that. You are much too young to remember, Vivian, but people predicted that it was going to be the end the brands and so forth. And in fact it wasn't, it was that when the consumers thought that the price gap was appropriate. They came right back into Marlboro. So Marlboro has that kind of equity and we would expect that as consumers continue to consolidate around premium brands, that Marlboro will do just fine.

componenttext: Yes, that's an interesting area to ask about. Thank you. headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us. We're here this morning with Marty Barrington, Altria's CEO; and Bill Gifford, Altria's CFO, to discuss Altria's 2015 first quarter business results. During our call today, unless otherwise stated, we are compar
componenttext: Good morning, and thank you for joining us. We're here this morning with Marty Barrington, Altria's CEO; and Bill Gifford, Altria's CFO, to discuss Altria's 2015 first quarter business results. During our call today, unless otherwise stated, we are comparing results to the same period in 2014. Earlier today, we issued a press release regarding our first quarter results. For a detailed review of them, please review the earnings release on our website at altria.com or via the Altria investor app. Our remarks contain forward-looking and cautionary statements and projections of future results. Please review the Forward-Looking and Cautionary Statement section at the end of today's earnings release for various factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from projections. Future dividend payments and share repurchases remains subject to the discretion of Altria's Board. The timing of share repurchases depends on marketplace conditions and other factors. Altria reports its financial result in accordance with U.S. Generally Accepted Accounting Principles. Today's call will contain various operating results on both a reported and adjusted basis, which excludes items that affect the comparability of reported results. Descriptions of these non-GAAP financial measures and reconciliations are included in today's earnings release, which is available on our website, and via the Altria investor app. Now I'll turn the call over to Marty.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sarah. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining our call. Altria is off to a strong start in 2015. Our core tobacco businesses continue to deliver on their strategies, backed by the strengths of their leading premium brands. Each of our repo
componenttext:
Thanks, Sarah. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining our call. Altria is off to a strong start in 2015. Our core tobacco businesses continue to deliver on their strategies, backed by the strengths of their leading premium brands. Each of our reportable segments grew operating company's income and expanded their margins. Altria grew it's adjusted diluted EPS by 10.5%, paid approximately $1 billion in dividends and repurchased 3.6 million shares in the first quarter, and earlier this morning we reaffirmed our guidance for 2015 full year adjusted diluted EPS growth of 7% to 9%. 
Here are some important highlights from the quarter. PM USA delivered on its multiple segment strategy of maximizing income while maintaining modest share momentum on Marlboro over time. The segment produced outstanding results in the first quarter, driven by higher pricing, higher volume and Marlboro retail share growth. PM USA has invested steadily to strengthen Marlboro and those investment continue to pay off. As a result, the smokable segment grew adjusted operating company's income by over 12% in the quarter. PM USA's reported cigarette shipment volumes grew 1.6% in the quarter, benefiting from a moderation in the industry decline rate, trade inventory movements and retail share gains. In the machine-made large cigar category, John Middleton continued to strengthen its leadership position in the profitable tipped cigar segment. The company posted strong double-digit volume growth in the quarter, driven primarily by Black & Mild. 
In the smokeless products segment, USSTC grew first quarter operating company's income by 5% and expanded its operating company's income margin by 1 percentage point to over 63%. USSTC estimates that it's adjusted smokeless segment volumes grew approximately 4% in the quarter, all smokeless industry volumes grew 2% over the past 12 months. Copenhagen and Skoal grew their combined retail share by 0.5 percentage point in the quarter. 
Turning to innovative tobacco products. Nu Mark remains focused on building a robust portfolio of innovative tobacco products for adult smokers and vapors. Nu Mark began shipping its next-generation e-vapor product, MarkTen XL into lead markets this month. 
In the line segment, Ste. Michelle posted a quarter of nearly 23% operating company's income growth, primarily through improved premium mix. In the first quarter, equity earnings from our SABMiller investment were negatively affected by SABMiller special items and unfavorable currency impacts from a stronger dollar. The investment continues to support our strong balance sheet and provides cash flow through its dividend. 
So we came into 2015 with momentum, and our first quarter results reflect another quarter of strong execution against our well-defined strategies. We believe our businesses are positioned to help us deliver against our full year guidance.
Billy Gifford will now discuss our business results in more detail.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Marty. Our smokeable product segment helped drive adjustment diluted EPS growth, up 10.5% in the first quarter. The smokeless product segment and fewer shares outstanding also contributed to that growth. The smokeable products segment delivered
componenttext:
Thank you, Marty. Our smokeable product segment helped drive adjustment diluted EPS growth, up 10.5% in the first quarter. The smokeless product segment and fewer shares outstanding also contributed to that growth. The smokeable products segment delivered strong adjusted operating company's income growth of 12.6%, primarily driven by higher pricing, higher shipment volume and lower resolution expenses, due primarily to the end of the federal tobacco quarter buyout payments. Despite costs being higher in the quarter, due primarily to higher pension and benefit cost and timing of SG&A spending, the smokable segment expanded its adjusted OCI  margins by 2.3 percentage points. Volume was also strong, after adjusting for trade inventory changes and other factors, PM USA estimates that its first quarter cigarette shipment volume was essentially unchanged, and the total industry volumes declined approximately 0.5%. For the quarter, PM USA grew Marlboro's retail share by 0.3 of a share point to 44%, and grew its total cigarette category retail share by 0.4 of a share point. L&M share gains also contributed to PM USA's first quarter performance as the brand continued to grow its share while the overall industry discount category declined in the quarter. In the total machine-made large cigars category, Black & Mild's retail share declined 0.6 of a share point in the first quarter. As Marty mentioned, Middleton continued to concentrate on the more profitable tipped cigar segment, were Black & Mild gain share. In the smokeless product segment, operating company's income increased 5% in the first quarter as higher pricing was partially offset by higher promotional investments. After adjusting for trade inventory changes and other factors, USSTC estimates that it's domestic smokeless product shipment volume grew approximately 4% in the quarter, while the industry grew approximately 2% over the past 12 months. Copenhagen and Skoal's combined retail share grew 0.5 of a share point in the quarter to 51.2%. Copenhagen's retail share grew 1 share point, while Skoal's retail share declined 0.5 of a share point. 
The line segment delivered very strong results in the first quarter. Ste. Michelle grew operating company's income by 22.7% in the first quarter, primarily driven by improved premium mix. Shipments increased by 0.5% in the quarter. That wraps up our operating results. Marty and I will now take your questions. While the calls are being compiled, lets cover a few housekeeping items. As a reminder, comparisons when made are against the first quarter of 2014, unless we note otherwise. Marlboro's price gap versus the lowest effective priced cigarette was 31% in the first quarter, down 2 percentage points. For the first quarter, Marlboro's net pack price was $6.06, up $0.15, and the lowest effective priced cigarette was $4.62, up $0.17. The estimated weighted average cigarette state excise tax was $1.49 per pack for the first quarter, up $0.01. 
Wholesale inventory changes are one factor PM USA uses to estimate adjusted PM USA and industry volumes. PM USA estimates that its wholesale inventories were approximately 2.6 billion units at the end of the first quarter of 2015 and 2.4 billion units at the end of the fourth quarter of 2014. At the end of the first quarter of 2014, PM USA's wholesale inventories were estimated to be approximately 2.5 billion units. PM USA estimates that cigarette industry wholesale inventory levels were 5.5 billion units at the end of the first quarter of 2015, and 5.4 billion units at the end of the fourth quarter of 2014. PM USA estimates that first quarter of 2014 wholesale inventory levels were 5.5 billion units. Copenhagen's price gap versus the leading discount brand was 29% in the first quarter, down 3 percentage points. Copenhagen's retail price was $4.22 in the first quarter, up $0.13. The price of the leading discount brand was $3.26 in the first quarter, up $0.17. CapEx was $48 million for the first quarter. Ongoing depreciation and amortization was $49 million for the quarter. Operator, do we have any questions?

componenttext: A couple of questions please. I mean, firstly, any commentary on the Marlboro Black, is that still taking share? If you could say, I mean, how much of Marlboro share growth is being driven by Black? And then, secondly, any update on recent market share trends for MarkTen. I noticed how you no longer have the statements about being amongst the top eBay programs nationally like you did at year end, should we read anything into that?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let's start with Marlboro Black. It continues to do a terrific job. In fact, it's grown for 17 consecutive quarters. We don't break the shares out by SKUs as you know, Owen, but Marlboro Black is doing a terrific job, particularly in the important s
componenttext: Sure. Let's start with Marlboro Black. It continues to do a terrific job. In fact, it's grown for 17 consecutive quarters. We don't break the shares out by SKUs as you know, Owen, but Marlboro Black is doing a terrific job, particularly in the important segment of adult smokers, 21 to 29. I hope you had a chance to see our remarks at CAGNY about our vapor business. Our aspiration there is to succeed in the long term. What that means is we're moving with appropriate dispatch, but with financial discipline, always learning from the consumer and frankly, what we're working on principally right now in addition to our distribution and brand building is product development. Consumers are telling eBay per manufacturers that the products are not yet there. That's why you see us improving our product development pipeline. And to be sure, share is important, but it will be important as soon as the products are established with the consumers. So we are not unduly focused on share. We are focused on getting the right products in the consumers hands.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from Bonnie Herzog of Wells Fargo.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: My first question is on consumption. Given the strong industry cigarette volume and the decelerating smokeless industry volume, do you have a sense of underlying total tobacco consumption when considering both of these categories? And then do you believe
componenttext: My first question is on consumption. Given the strong industry cigarette volume and the decelerating smokeless industry volume, do you have a sense of underlying total tobacco consumption when considering both of these categories? And then do you believe it's rising and if so why? And then maybe touch on your outlook for the cigarette decline rates. Is a 3% to 4% decline rate realistic going forward?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great, thanks for those questions. Let me start with cigarette volume. We don't forecast volume forward as you know. It's been 3% to 4% over the last several years, and we think that you have to look at that over time. To be sure this quarter, is a
componenttext: Okay, great, thanks for those questions. Let me start with cigarette volume. We don't forecast volume forward as you know. It's been 3% to 4% over the last several years, and we think that you have to look at that over time. To be sure this quarter, is a break, but it's only a quarter, so we'll have to see. Probably the best answer to your question about consumption is, the total consumption rate over the last several years as measured by government sources, which has been declining at about, call it 1% to 1.5% total pounds. So that takes into account, Bonnie, all of the products that adult tobacco consumers are trying. And of course, it's a dynamic time. We have seen more moment among the categories. That's probably the best marker.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll try to give you a little help. It's in the all other category as you know. And so we don't -- going to break it out too much under that. But we're in an investment mode. And that's the best way to understand it. And in response to Owen's question, I
componenttext: I'll try to give you a little help. It's in the all other category as you know. And so we don't -- going to break it out too much under that. But we're in an investment mode. And that's the best way to understand it. And in response to Owen's question, I pointed out that we have a lot of work underway to make sure that we have a robust portfolio of products, because that's what the consumer is saying to everyone, which is "I'm willing to try these products, but they're not quite there yet." So we are continually working to improve our offerings. That's why we've come out with MarkTen XL, twice the battery size and so forth. And so I think that's a way to understand it, and we're going to be in investment mode here, but we do it in a financially disciplined way, always cognizant of our long-term financial goal of 7% to 9% growth in our EPS. And we've been able to pull that off and I'm confident that we will over time.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And then speaking of MarkTen XL, when do you expect that to be a nationwide expansion. I think you mentioned you're rolling out into lead markets? And then how incremental do you anticipate this is going to be? And how concerned are you with cannibalization for that extension?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we'll talk about national once we get in lead markets and we see how it does. That's our innovation system, which is to put products in consumers hands, conducting experiments about whether the offering is interesting to them, find out how we can im
componenttext: Well, we'll talk about national once we get in lead markets and we see how it does. That's our innovation system, which is to put products in consumers hands, conducting experiments about whether the offering is interesting to them, find out how we can improve it and then we roll forward. And you saw that's how we did MarkTen. I think that's what you should expect with MarkTen XL.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And then just my final last question is on your discount volume has been strong, especially O&M. So I'd like to hear what's been driving that, especially, given the stronger consumer? And maybe here have you touched on how you're balancing the growth of this segment with margin expansion? And what your strategy is in this space?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Good questions, both. We -- look our focus is on the premium end of the business, more than 90% of PM USA cigarette shipments are premium, and that's where the action is for us. But of course, there is a discount segment out there. It's declining ove
componenttext: Yes. Good questions, both. We -- look our focus is on the premium end of the business, more than 90% of PM USA cigarette shipments are premium, and that's where the action is for us. But of course, there is a discount segment out there. It's declining over time. The real reason that we're growing our discount business there is because of L&M. It's a terrific product that's price competitively in the marketplace and it's doing great. So it's not our principal focus, but it does help the business, albeit small.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from Chris Growe of Stifel.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just had a question for you. This is -- several quarters in a row where the price gap between Marlboro and the lowest price product in the market has been down, and even taking very strong pricing. I just have 2 questions around that. One would be, as you
componenttext: Just had a question for you. This is -- several quarters in a row where the price gap between Marlboro and the lowest price product in the market has been down, and even taking very strong pricing. I just have 2 questions around that. One would be, as you look at your promotional spending overall in the quarter, could you say that was up or down, and I mean, for the cigarette business overall? And then, is there any -- are you pulling back on promotions, say in the premium side versus discount to help widen that gap, assuming that you need a little better economics position today and plus that gap could widen a bit from this level?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks for your questions. Let me go out at this way. We had net pricing realization in the cigarette in the smokable segment more than 5%, so you can see that despite the fact that the price gap's narrowed, we're, as you point out taking strong pri
componenttext: Okay. Thanks for your questions. Let me go out at this way. We had net pricing realization in the cigarette in the smokable segment more than 5%, so you can see that despite the fact that the price gap's narrowed, we're, as you point out taking strong pricing, which is great. The reason the price gap's narrowed in the quarter is because some discount brands increased their pricing faster than the premium brands did, and that's what accounts for the math, including some rounding frankly when you do the math in the price gaps. So price gaps are important metric as we've spoken about, and we keep an eye on them. But boy, to have a quarter where we can grow our volume, grow our margin, get strong pricing realization, you can see the result of that Chris with nearly 13% operating company income growth. That's pretty good algorithm for us. Price gap's narrowing or not. Billy you want to say a word about promotional spend?

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think if you think about it Chris, you'll recall last year we actually had started dialing back promotional spend around Marlboro, and so we're lapping that as we go through the first quarter.
componenttext: Yes, I think if you think about it Chris, you'll recall last year we actually had started dialing back promotional spend around Marlboro, and so we're lapping that as we go through the first quarter.

headline: Altria Group Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
